commitResults.messageBody:
Let's rename Duke.java into MoiMoi.java, and implement a skeletal
version of the chatbot that simply greets the user and exits.

Let's add an echoing functionality to MoiMoi.java such that it echoes
commands entered by the user, and exits when the user types the command
"bye".

Let's,
* add a functionality for the chatbot to store whatever text entered by
the user
* add a functionality to display (in list-form) all inputs that have
been stored, when requested by the user

Let's,
* create a class named "Task" to represent tasks stored and tracked by
the chatbot
* add a functionality for the chatbot to mark tasks as done
* add a functionality for the chatbot to unmark completed tasks (ie.
mark tasks as undone)

The "Task" class encapsulates a String description, and the completion
status of a task.

Let's add a class named Parser to streamline input parsing, by
separating the command and arguments. This modular approach enhances
maintainability, making future modifications (if any) to input handling
more manageable.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add support for tracking tasks of various types
commitResults.messageBody:
Let's,
* create subclasses of Task, namely Todo, Event and Deadline,
leveraging inheritance to extend shared properties and behaviors
* add functionalities for the chatbot to appropriately handle (eg.
store, track etc.) tasks of the aforementioned types

The input/output redirection technique is used to semi-automate the
testing of MoiMoi.

Let's,
* edit runtest.bat, substituting any instance of "Duke" into
"MoiMoi"
* add a file containing a series of user inputs, named input.txt
* add a file containing expected outputs corresponding to the
aforementioned inputs, named EXPECTED.TXT

MoiMoi's logo has been changed (in MoiMoi.java). It now consists of
mappable ASCII characters for encoding.

Let's create exception classes to facilitate error-handling.

The abstract class "MoiMoiException" represents all exceptions
specific to MoiMoi. Its subclasses, "InvalidCommandException",
"MissingArgumentException" and "InvalidArgumentException" address
specific errors that MoiMoi may encounter during execution.

Let's,
* Edit MoiMoi.java (and Parser.java) such that it appropriately
handles errors, mainly due to incorrect user inputs
* include error-related scenarios, to be tested on MoiMoi, in
input.txt and EXPECTED.TXT

MoiMoi supports adding tasks, but is unable to delete tasks
specified by the user.

Users may then find it hard to manage their task lists effectively,
especially when they need to remove tasks.

Let's,
* modify MoiMoi.java to support deleting tasks as specified by the
user
* include corresponding tests in input.txt and EXPECTED.TXT

This ensures flexibility in MoiMoi's task management operations,
aligning with user expectations for basic task management
functionalities.

The 'case' branches in MoiMoi.java are indented.

This can lead to unnecessary nesting and doesn't align with the
module's coding standards.

Let's remove indentations for 'case' branches in MoiMoi.java.

This improves code readability and ensures compliance with the
module’s coding standards.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add storage-specific String method for task classes
commitResults.messageBody:
Tasks have a "toString" method that returns a String representation
of the task's information.

However, tasks need a separate way to format their information as a
String for storage purposes, which is different from the format
used in the UI.

Let's,
* create a new field in Task named "typeIcon" to generalize task
types
* implement a new method that returns a String of the task’s
information formatted for storage

This separation ensures that the data stored in files is consistent
with the expected format during loading, while keeping the UI
representation clean and focused on display purposes.

MoiMoi lacks specific exception classes to handle IO errors and
corrupted data files during storage operations.

Handling storage-related errors will make the codebase more robust and
allow clearer error messaging.

Let's,
* create an exception class, named "StorageCorruptedException", to
represent errors related to corrupted data files (i.e., when the content
is not in its expected format)
* create an exception class, named "StorageIOException", to represent IO
errors that may occur during data file creation or saving

These exceptions encapsulate storage-related errors, which can be easily
handled and managed.

MoiMoi is unable to persist tasks between sessions.

Persistent storage is an expected task management feature, as users need
to save tasks and load them in future sessions.

Let's,
* create a class named "Storage" to encapsulate the data file used
to store tasks, along with methods for loading and saving. If the data
file does not exist, a new one will automatically be created
* modify MoiMoi.java to utilize the Storage class for task persistence

By centralizing storage logic in a class, the codebase becomes cleaner
and easier to maintain. Users are enabled to save and load tasks between
program runs.

MoiMoi lacks specific exception classes to handle date-time errors.

Handling date-time-related errors will make the codebase more robust and
allow clearer error messaging.

Let's,
* create an exception class, named "InvalidDateTimeException", to
represent errors related to incorrect formatting of date and time
* create an exception class, named "InvalidDateTimeRangeException", to
represent errors in which the starting time of an event is later than
its ending time
* rename "InvalidArgumentException" as "InvalidIndexException" to
specifically handle errors related to incorrect task indices

"InvalildDateTimeException" and "InvalildDateTimeRangeException"
encapsulate date-time-related errors, making them easier to handle and
manage.

Date-times are stored as strings in "Deadline" and "Event" tasks.

MoiMoi is unable to perform date-time validation, which can lead to
errors and reduces the effectiveness of task management.

Let's,
* store date-time information as "java.time.LocalDateTime" objects in
both "Deadline" and "Event" tasks
* modify MoiMoi.java and Storage.java to handle date-time parsing and
formatting
* include date-time-related scenarios, to be tested on MoiMoi, in
input.txt and EXPECTED.TXT

Utilizing LocalDateTime provides robust handling of date-time
information in the chatbot, facilitating better task management.

The "InvalidDateTimeException" is thrown only for "LocalDateTime"
parsing errors.

The "LocalDate" class to be introduced later can also throw parsing
errors. These are also expected to be handled using the
"InvalidDateTimeException" class.

Let's,
* generalize "InvalidDateTimeException" to represent errors thrown by
either "LocalDateTime" and "LocalDate" parsing methods
* ensure that the exception returns appropriate error messages specific
to the type of date-time object being parsed

This implementation prepares MoiMoi to handle both "LocalDateTime" and
"LocalDate" parsing errors. Users are able to receive clear and relevant
error messages if such issues arise.

MoiMoi currently lacks functionality that makes proper use of date-time
objects after they are validated.

Handling date-time objects meaningfully can enhance task management,
specifically by allowing users to filter tasks by specific dates.

Let's,
* create a method within tasks to check if they occur on a specific date
* add a command for MoiMoi that filters and prints deadlines/events
occurring on a specific date
* include date-filtering-related scenarios, to be tested on MoiMoi, in
input.txt and EXPECTED.TXT

This provides meaningful use of date and time, as users are able to
filter and view tasks based on specific dates.

MoiMoi handles user interactions and task management directly within its
main class.

This makes the program not easy to maintain and extend.

Let's,
* extract a "Ui" class to handle I/O interactions with the user
* extract a "TaskList" class to manage the task list and provide
operations to add/delete tasks
* modify MoiMoi.java and Storage.java to utilize the aforementioned
classes, within their operations

This makes the codebase more modular and maintainable.

MoiMoi's operations (and their corresponding commands) are represented
as strings.

This approach limits extensibility and makes the codebase hard to
maintain.

Let's,
* create an abstract "Command" class to represent chatbot commands
* implement subclasses of "Command" for each specific operation,
encapsulating the execution logic

This improves the code structure and makes it easier to extend or modify
commands in the future.

commitResults.messageTitle: MoiMoi.java: utilize Parser class and Command objects
commitResults.messageBody:
MoiMoi.java contains both input parsing logic and the logic for
executing all operations.

This makes the codebase difficult to maintain and extend.

Let's,
* refactor "Parser" methods to convert user input directly into
executable Command objects
* remove parsing and command execution logic from MoiMoi.java, while
delegating these responsibilities to both "Parser" and "Command" classes

This simplifies MoiMoi.java and improves maintainability with a better
separation of concerns.

Subtle modifications in MoiMoi's running logic have led to slight
changes in the UI display formats.

Adjustments are necessary to ensure that the output layout remains
consistent with the desired format.

Let's,
* modify Ui.java to align the output format with the updated program
logic
* update EXPECTED.TXT to reflect the desired output

This ensures that the UI remains intuitive, clear and consistent.

During input parsing, commands are directly converted from strings into
"Command" objects.

This approach lacks structure and is prone to errors due to direct raw
string handling.

Let's,
* create an Enum named "CommandEnum" to represent all command types
supported by MoiMoi
* modify Parser.java and AddCommand.java to utilize command enumerations

This enhances the robustness and clarity of the codebase, by replacing
raw string handling with a more structured approach.

Command classes are located on the same directory level as other classes
used by MoiMoi.

This unorganized and cluttered project structure makes the codebase
harder to maintain as the number of classes increases.

Let's create a package named "moimoi.command" and move all
command-related classes into this package.

This improves code maintainability by grouping related classes together.
The codebase also becomes cleaner and easier to navigate.

Exception classes are located on the same directory level as other
classes used by MoiMoi.

This unorganized and cluttered project structure makes the codebase
harder to maintain as the number of classes increases.

Let's create a package named "moimoi.exception" and move all
exception classes into this package.

This improves code maintainability by grouping related classes together.
The codebase also becomes cleaner and easier to navigate.

Task classes are located on the same directory level as other classes
used by MoiMoi.

This unorganized and cluttered project structure makes the codebase
harder to maintain as the number of classes increases.

Let's,
* create and utilize an Enum named "TaskEnum" representing all task
types supported by MoiMoi, to enhance code robustness
* create a package named "moimoi.task" and move all task-related classes
into this package

This improves code maintainability by grouping related classes together.
The codebase also becomes cleaner and easier to navigate.

commitResults.messageTitle: Move general classes to moimoi package
commitResults.messageBody:
General classes are not organized under any package.

This lack of structure makes the codebase hard to navigate and maintain
as it grows.

Let's,
* move general classes into the "moimoi" package
* edit runtest.bat to include .java files from all packages, ensuring
that they are compiled and available during testing

This ensures that all classes related to MoiMoi are under the "moimoi"
package, with general classes in the root and grouped classes in sub
packages, improving clarity and maintainability.

The initial Gradle configuration in build.gradle includes settings and
identifiers related to Duke's project setup.

These references prevent Gradle-associated tasks from running on
MoiMoi.

Let's,
* update the "application.mainClass" reference to reflect the correct
main class
* update the "shadowJar.archiveBaseName" reference

This ensures that Gradle can run tasks and produce correct outputs
aligned with MoiMoi's project setup.

Minor flaws in the UI display formats are found.

Adjustments are necessary to ensure that the output layout remains
consistent with the desired format.

Let's modify Ui.java to align the output layouts with their desired
formats.

This ensures that the UI remains intuitive, clear and consistent.

MoiMoi only has I/O comparison tests.

There are no dedicated tests for individual methods, which makes it hard
to ensure their correctness.

Let's add appropriate JUnit tests to test the behavior of non-trivial
methods in MoiMoi.

This improves test coverage and allows verification of the correctness
of each method's logic, ensuring overall robustness of MoiMoi.

The codebase lacks detailed documentation.

This makes it hard for future developers to understand and
maintain the code.

Let's add header comments to all non-trivial classes and methods.

This improves code readability and maintainability, by providing
clear explanations of non-trivial classes and methods.

commitResults.messageTitle: Align code with course's coding standards
commitResults.messageBody:
The codebase has some discrepancies when compared to the course's
coding standards.

Without adhering to coding standards, code can be hard to maintain
and navigate.

Let's make necessary adjustments to the code to comply with the
course's coding standards.

This ensures code consistency, clarity and maintainability.

MoiMoi does not support searching for tasks by keyword.

This limits MoiMoi's usability, as keyword search is an expected
functionality for effective task management.

Let's,
* add a command class named "FindCommand" that allows MoiMoi to
filter and print tasks containing a specific keyword in their
descriptions
* modify relevant classes to implement the "find" operation, by
integrating the "FindCommand" class

This improves user experience by allowing efficient task searching
and management.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add JUnit tests for find-by-keyword functionality
commitResults.messageBody:
The newly added find-by-keyword functionality is untested.

Testing is essential to ensure that the "find" feature works as
expected.

Let's add JUnit tests to verify non-trivial methods used throughout
the "find" process.

This helps identify any issues early and ensures that the "find"
feature performs accurately under different scenarios.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update files for I/O redirection testing
commitResults.messageBody:
Files for I/O redirection testing do not include test cases for the
newly added find-by-keyword feature.

These files need to be updated to reflect the increments made.

Let's,
* update input.txt and EXPECTED.TXT to include test cases for the
"find" feature
* adjust the configuration in runtest.bat to correctly redirect I/O
during testing
* modify StorageIOException.java to align with expected output
formats

This helps to validate that the find-by-keyword functionality and
its related outputs are working as intended.

# Conflicts:
#	src/main/java/moimoi/exception/InvalidDateTimeException.java
#	src/main/java/moimoi/task/Task.java

Resolution: ensure adherence to the course's coding standards

# Conflicts:
#	src/main/java/moimoi/Parser.java
#	src/main/java/moimoi/Ui.java
#	src/main/java/moimoi/task/Task.java

Resolution: ensure correct positioning of JavaDoc comments and
adherence to the course's coding standards

# Conflicts:
# src/main/java/moimoi/Parser.java
# src/main/java/moimoi/Ui.java
# src/main/java/moimoi/task/Task.java

Resolution: ensure correct positioning of JavaDoc comments and
adherence to the course's coding standards

# Conflicts:
#	src/main/java/moimoi/Ui.java

Resolution: retain line to align with code logic

The "TaskList" class contains a method named "size()".

This does not adhere to the course's coding standards, which
requires using verbs for method names.

Let's rename "size()" to "getSize()" and update all references to
the method accordingly.

This enhances code readability and clarity.

Keyword matching during "find" operations is case-sensitive.

A case-insensitive searching is more user-friendly, as users are not
expected to remember the exact case of keywords.

Let's,
* update the "find" operation to use case-insensitive keyword
matching
* update input.txt, EXPECTED.TXT and relevant JUnit tests, to
include test cases for the new format

This improves functionality for the "find" feature, making it more
intuitive for users of MoiMoi.

commitResults.messageTitle: Integrate Checkstyle to enforce coding standards
commitResults.messageBody:
There is no automated enforcement of coding standards within the
project.

Adhering to a consistent coding style is essential for more
maintainable and readable code.

Let's,
* create and update Checkstyle configuration files accordingly
* modify code to resolve violations identified by Checkstyle

This improves code quality, by ensuring that the codebase adheres
to a consistent coding standard.

MoiMoi uses a Command Line Interface (CLI).

This needs to change to provide a more user-friendly experience.

Let's,
* add necessary classes and FXML files, using JavaFX for Graphical
User Interface (GUI) development
* update the codebase to incorporate and utilize the GUI classes
* adapt JUnit test files accordingly, as well as remove classes,
references and test files related to the outdated CLI
* repackage classes (mainly reorganizing GUI and utility
classes) for a clearer and more maintainable project structure

Implementing an intuitive GUI enhances MoiMoi's visual interactions
with its users.

MoiMoi's GUI design is functional but can be further refined.

A change is needed to improve aesthetics.

Let's,
* add .css files as style sheets
* tweak GUI configurations to achieve the desired layout and design

The enhancement in GUI improves MoiMoi's overall user experience.

The codebase does not include the use of the 'assert' feature.

This needs to change to document important assumptions and ensure
that they hold at various points in the code.

Let's add assertions to enforce these assumptions.

This improves code reliability by helping us catch potential bugs
earlier in the development process.

The code consists of areas that could be made more maintainable and
readable.

This needs to change to ensure that the code follows best practices
for maintainability and clarity.

Let's refactor the code where necessary.

By ensuring that the code aligns with established principles, this
improves overall code quality.
Add assertions
Improve code quality

commitResults.messageTitle: Add support for managing fixed duration tasks
commitResults.messageBody:
MoiMoi does not support fixed duration tasks that do not have a
specific start or end time.

This needs to change so that users are allowed to manage such tasks.

Let's add functionality to manage fixed duration (period) tasks.

This enhances MoiMoi's task management capabilities, making it more
versatile for various user needs.

The JUnit tests could be better structured.

This needs to change to ensure that the tests are clear and
maintainable.

Let's refactor the JUnit tests.

This enhances test-code readability and maintainability.

The JUnit tests could be better structured.

This needs to change to ensure that the tests are clear and
maintainable.

Let's refactor the JUnit tests.

This enhances test-code readability and maintainability.

MoiMoi's GUI displays both sides of the conversation in the same visual
format.

This needs to change to better reflect the asymmetric nature of
interactions between the user and the program.

Let's tweak the GUI design to distinguish between user and MoiMoi dialog
boxes.

This makes the user interface more visually intuitive, and improves user
experience.

The project lacks a user guide.

This makes it hard for new users to understand how to use MoiMoi.

Let's,
* create a comprehensive user guide
* include a screenshot of the GUI for visual reference

By providing clear instructions on how to interact with the chatbot,
this improves the user onboarding experience.

README.md contains a minor typo that inaccurately describes MoiMoi's
behavior.

This needs to change to ensure that the user guide is consistent
with the chatbot's behavior.

Let's fix the typo.

This keeps the user guide clear and correct, providing a reliable
reference for users.
